I have discussed the issue with @rabbah. He proposed more general solution.

activation entity records can be divided into two parts: small constant size and unbounded size. logs, result object are examples of the latter. The other fields of an activation are finite and bounded
Default activation list should get and show a bounded part of each activation. activation list with a flag (include_docs) should get everything that belongs to activation.

I will do the changes in this direction. Any comments?

Rebased and [merged](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/compare/cf6029e14434...e5c4e58f8dfe) with an additional correction.
Fixed with #216.

Both the `create` and `update` operations are PUT operations on their respective collection. The API guards the former so that an overwrite flag is required to update an entity if it already exists. This query parameter `?overwrite=true` is provided by the `update` operation. Hence the semantics of `update` are to create if entity does not exist else to update.

When updating an action, the executable and parameters are optional since they already exist.

It is often more convenient when using setup and teardown scripts to use `update` instead of `create`.
It is clear to me now, thanks Rabbah
As a corollary to this creating an action in the context of a package could be done through `[POST] /namespaces/{namespaceName}/packages/{packageName}/actions`

Actions that are not in an explicitly named package are considered part of the `default` package. In this way, we can consider unifying the packages and actions API endpoints in this way `/namespaces/{namespaceName}/packages/{packageName}/actions/{actionName}` and reserve the package name `default`. In fact, we can take this further and eschew the packages endpoints all together, unifying the entity types in the same way.

The trigger and action that make a rule must be in the default package, which is in fact _private_. The docs should state this, you are right, and the API/CLI should report a better error message.

We plan to relax the noted constraint so that you can create a rule using an action in a package.

Assigning to @jeremiaswerner with the docker 1.11 work
@rabbah @ioana-blue We can discuss based on this PR.

Why are we doing the statsd pushes in the core? Wasn't the plan to do push from the logstash forwarder using the statsd plugin?

A few concerns about doing it this way:
1. `sendToStatsd` is called on every log emit - for multiple markers, so the costs per log message in proportional to marker maps
2. the statsd writer is an instance of `NonBlockingUdpSender` which uses a single thread to push to `statsd`, so all pushes are [serialized in this executor](https://github.com/tim-group/java-statsd-client/blob/master/src/main/java/com/timgroup/statsd/NonBlockingUdpSender.java)
3. there is no batching in place as far as I can tell (or aggregation), and this might impact performance - we need to quantify any performance implications

@rabbah we agree that we can move statsd call into the Logstash. we also thought that statsd calls in transactionId is not the best way. Our idea is to calculate deltas in the transaction context and just do send action in the Logstash.

You may be able to do the deltas in Logstash as well, so you could move all the logic to Logstash. I think for the use cases you are interested in, the log messages appear in the same file. If that's the case, you can use this plugin: [elapsed](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/logstash/current/plugins-filters-elapsed.html) and compute the deltas and then send them to statsd.

@ioana-blue @rabbah We want to do more fine-grained metrics. Not a duration of whole transaction or from transaction start to some point in a transaction. We also want to measure duration of external calls separately. After the first implementation from Ioana, we did not consider doing calculation in the Logstash. Because we thought that it is not possible to do that in the Logstash. Btw, we are not experienced with Logstash. Thus we implemented in the transaction context.

@fxulusoy Give Logstash a try. It's fairly simple to use the elapsed plugin. I didn't know Logstash either, but you can read some of the documentation and it's fairly straightforward. Take a look at the plugin and let me know if you have questions, we can chat over Skype if necessary.

@fxulusoy The reason we want to offload from the controller is that it is at the central component and performance critical.  By emitting one UDP packet  per log, we would end up generating much more traffic in service os a single activation than the one call coming in.  So offloading work form the controller and some sort of batching is important and why I think we are pushing Logstash.

@perryibm I totally agree with your concerns about performance. As I said in one of my previous comment, making UDP calls per log is wrong. The PR is just a prototype to show our idea and we just put UPD calls there for a moment. The goal of PR is to show how we want to calculate the deltas not how /where to call statsd. we will have a look logstash and the related plugin and give a try.

this looks pretty good. i would like it if it could get:

1) field-level descriptions; e.g. payload's description would be something like "The text to verbalize"; and what is voice? a description here would help maybe linking to a doc page that gives the options, along with a sample input for voice

2) this is one case where i'd love to explore mime typing the I/O, output specifically in this case. @perryibm has suggested that we could use the browser's richer I/O capabilities; e.g. to offer the output as an audio playback widget. could we testbed this idea, here?

3) could we use this opportunity to enrich the package-level metadata? a) a branding annotation "IBM Watson (TM) Whatever", and an icon annotation (does Watson have one?), and a homepage link, to start with.

`wsk invoke --blocking <action-name>` if the response code is 200, the result of the activation is printed, but not its logs. if the response code is different than 200, the start/end timestamps + the logs get printed. what I care about is logs when the response code is 200. 

I have to note that this is cod run by a new python action that I'm adding. If I need to do anything special to get the logs printed, let me know, I thought that part of the code is language-agnostic.

The API response is the same. The CLI, when you run with `--blocking`, in addition to printing the activation id as with non-blocking activations, will also project the result. If you want the full activation record or just the logs, of course you can get it by its id.

This behavior predated the introduction of `--result` so we could report the full activation record in the absence of `--result` and only the result in case of the latter.

To make this change, modify this [line](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/cli/wskaction.py#L125) 

```
-                print getPrettyJson(result['response'])
+                print getPrettyJson(result)
```
Actually thinking more about it, it seems the value is not necessarily a JSON "object" but can be an integer or any JSON "value". So maybe adding "type": "object" is not the correct fix here.
Indeed - a legal value for a parameter or annotation is any legal JSON value: object, array, number, string, boolean or null.

at some point, we may also want to consider per-action icons. e.g. Watson seems to have a TTS icon: http://www.ibm.com/cloud-computing/bluemix/watson/

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4741620/14862073/debb55d0-0c7d-11e6-8190-792e1c66d007.png)

i suggest that we start with hrefs to externally hosted icons. later, we may consider that these are part of the package bundle itself, i.e. hosted by openwhisk, though still presented as hrefs to clients.

@joachimvaldez has suggested this icon for Watson
![](https://developer.ibm.com/bluemix/wp-content/uploads/sites/20/2014/10/watsonLogo.png)

we also may want to distinguish "icons" into two separate fields:
1. **branding**: large-scale iconography, that may e.g. include the company trademark
2. **inline icon**: small-scale iconography that can be used alongside entity listings, etc.

for example, for cloudant, a "branding" attribute might be
http://s3.amazonaws.com/topvouch-company-logos/softwares/logos/000/001/422/original/raw?1421826754
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4741620/14853292/ec1ba204-0c58-11e6-9266-11bdd4e3176c.png)

and an inline-icon attribute might be 
![](https://cloudant.com/wp-content/uploads/cloudant_logo_icon_events.png)

Configuring the docker image to use Swift 3 will require changes to the Dockerfile as well as the epilogue.swift file which adds serialization support currently not in Foundation.  Due to some restrictions in Swift 3, we also have to explicitly name the parameter field for a Swift action, e.g. require that it be called "args", rather than leave the name up to the developer.
